3: xmobar is a lightweight, text-based, status bar written in Haskell. It
4: was originally designed to be used together with Xmonad, but it is also
5: usable with any other Window Manager. While xmobar is written in
6: Haskell, no knowledge of the language is required to install and use it.
27: xmobar is in the community repository and can be installed with pacman:

13: The configuration for xmobar is normally defined in ~/.xmobarrc or by
14: specifying a set of command line options when launching xmobar. Any
15: given command line option will override the corresponding option in the
16: configuration file. This can be useful to test new configurations
17: without having to edit a configuration file.
